problem: A 150-g ball at the end of a string is revolving uniformly in a horizontal circle of radius 0.600 m. The ball makes 2.00 revolutions in a second. What is its centripetal acceleration?

steps.explanation: Uniform circular motion requires a centripetal acceleration directed toward the center; its magnitude can be written either in terms of linear speed or rotational frequency.
Relate the given revolution rate to the period of motion to check consistency.
Compute the tangential speed using the circumference traversed in each revolution.
Insert the speed and radius into the centripetal acceleration expression.
State the final magnitude (about 9.7 g) directed toward the center of the circular path.
